New Records: Bangladesh set a new World Cup record for most sixes in an innings with Mahmudullah's two late sixes
Key Match Events: Mitchell blazes Shoriful over midwicket for his fourth six, sealing victory for New Zealand with more than eight overs to spare
Daryl Mitchell plays a reverse sweep
Kane Williamson was hit on the thumb of his left hand
Shakib Al Hasan produces the goods, sliding past an attempted reverse-sweep and extracting three reds on DRS
Taskin Ahmed enjoyed a slap-happy knock of 17 from 19 balls, including a vast six over cow corner
Mitchell Santner's own finale proves far more fruitful, with a frustrated slog sweep off the sixth ball of his tenth over
Lockie Ferguson's third wicket of a superbly hostile spell, and New Zealand have done their homework here
Mushfiqur Rahim helped Bangladesh recover with a 57th ODI half-century, his ninth in World Cups, and his second in consecutive innings
Trent Boult strikes first ball, and it's a birthday duck for Das
Bangladesh's Old Firm, Shakib Al Hasan and Mushfiqur Rahim, piece together a faltering innings with a diet of singles
Lockie Ferguson is into the action in his first over, and it's a floppy dismissal from Tanzid Hasan
Bangladesh's batting average (30.75) against short-pitched fast bowling is poor, and their strike rate (85.64) against this length is the worst among everyone here

What's the verdict? Here's what our Matchday team had to say about the prospect of a spinning wicket in Chennai
New Zealand seek third win as Bangladesh look to bounce back
Post-Match Reflections: Mitchell and Phillips have ensured there will be nothing further for New Zealand fans to worry about in this chase
A thoroughly comprehensive job, New Zealand move to six points and back on top of the table
Miscellaneous Highlights: The uppercut has been a feature of Mushfiqur's game today, and out it comes once more, for a firm biff through deep backward point off the extra pace of Lockie Ferguson
Bangladesh possess a clutch of the most experienced campaigners in all of World Cup history
Shakib Al Hasan and Mushfiqur Rahim are both playing in their fifth tournament - only Sachin Tendulkar and Javed Miandad, with six, have lasted longer
Others: It's the first time in Men's World Cup history that New Zealand have struck with the first ball of a match
New Zealand have beaten Bangladesh in each of their last nine completed ODIs, dating back to February 2019
